title: 103_hr1671
content: The Act is titled the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act" and includes Congressional findings. The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall, Old City Hall, and Independence Hall, need federal preservation due to financial constraints and the National Park Service's expanded responsibilities. The Congress acknowledges the National Park Service's responsibility for maintaining historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. Minting a commemorative coin to support the preservation of these sites is deemed appropriate. The Congress acknowledges the National Park Service's responsibility for maintaining historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. Minting a commemorative coin to support the preservation of these sites is deemed appropriate. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to issue up to 1,000,000 $1 coins, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, with inscriptions including the year "1994" and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins will be considered numismatic items and legal tender. The coins issued under subsection (a) shall be legal tender as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the authorized coins from stockpiles. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Advisory Committee. The coins will be legal tender. The Secretary will sell the authorized coins at face value plus costs and a $7 surcharge. Bulk sales will be discounted, and prepaid orders accepted. The coins will be legal tender. The coins authorized under section 3 may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with a limit of 1 facility for each quality. The Secretary can start issuing the coins on July 4, 1994, and minting can begin 30 days after the enactment of the Act for up to 1 year. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT RELATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods or services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. The Secretary shall distribute surcharges from coin sales: 50% to reduce national debt, 50% to Independence Hall Preservation Fund for capital improvements and projects in Independence National Historic Park. SEC. 10. The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditures. SEC. 11. Financial assurances are required. SEC. 11. Financial assurances are necessary to ensure no net cost to the government for minting and issuing coins under this Act. Payment must be received in full, with satisfactory security or guarantee from a depository institution.
